intro: Hyssopus officinalis var. ambiguus, commonly known as the lesser hyssop, is a perennial herb native to southern Europe and western Asia. It typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring opposite, lance-shaped leaves with a slightly hairy surface. The plant produces spikes of pale blue to violet flowers, which bloom in late spring to early summer. It thrives in well-drained soil and full sun, often found in rocky or dry habitats. This variety is valued for its aromatic properties and historical use in herbal medicine.
